newsitem.title: JAPAN: JGBs higher, off new highs, on late profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: JGBs higher, off new highs, on late profit-taking.

text.p: Cash yen bonds and futures stayed above the previous day's finish in late Tokyo on Wednesday but slipped back from new highs on aggressive profit-taking.
Key June 10-year Japanese government bond (JGB) futures closed offer-only after being last traded at 126.62, up 0.67 from Tuesday's finish. The June's session low was 126.32.

The June hit a new high for any benchmark contract at 126.92 in the afternoon, buoyed by a continued buying spree in long-term cash bonds after the release of the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) key "tankan" corporate survey in the morning.
The survey revealed weak sentiment at non-manufacturing and smaller firms. The June diffusion index was also weak.

"Those who had sold cash bonds on speculation of a strong tankan bought back quickly, while those who had failed to buy during the recent rallies also joined in a buying spree this afternoon," said a dealer at a trust bank's securities unit.
Before the tankan's release, rumours emerged that the June diffusion index might be plus one, a strong figure, prompting cash bond sales that lifted the key JGB yield to 2.285 percent.
The yield of the benchmark 182nd 10-year cash JGB later fell to 2.140 percent, a record low for any benchmark JGB.
The yield stood at 2.175 percent at 0712 GMT, still sharply down from Tuesday's 2.255 percent.

"The tankan gave mixed signals on Japan's economy as business sentiment at big manufacturers' was good, while small businesses and non-manufacturers were not doing well," said a senior dealer at a city bank's securities unit.
"But given the recent buoyant tone in JGBs, the neutral result was a buy signal for many investors," he said.
The diffusion index for big manufacturers for June was minus one, while the June index for big non-manufacturers was minus seven, the BOJ said.
The diffusion index for June was minus 13 for small manufacturers and minus 14 for small non-manufacturers, the BOJ said.
The March diffusion index for big manufacturers was plus two, up from minus three in the November survey, the BOJ said.
The market, buoyed by strong demand for JGBs from life insurers and other investors, ignored moderately optimistic remarks on the tankan survey by a senior BOJ official.
Masayuki Matsushima, director of the BOJ's Research and Statistics Department, said Japan's economy is continuing its gradual recovery, with private demand becoming firmer.
Traders said the cash bond buying spree was later fuelled by a report that MOF's Trust Fund Bureau will shift its investment focus to holding JGBs for five years and longer.

A MOF official told Reuters that the bureau has now more freedom to invest than in the past. The bureau's plan to buy 2.4 trillion yen worth of long-term JGBs in fiscal 1997/98 was approved by the parliament last month, enabling the bureau to hold long-term JGBs for five years and longer.
"MOF's regular buying is usually too small to have a strong impact. But many bought on the news as the market was bullish," said a dealer at a Big-Four brokerage. -- Risa Maeda
